text: It depends a lot on the country. IANAL, but the main problem is not the legal requirement or not, but the fact that you never want to be on the other side of an AML check, they are pretty..invasive (and they tend to freeze all your assets if they have some doubt, *then* ask questions -- at least that's what i hear from some of the bank compliance friends).

elements.text: It depends a lot on the country. IANAL, but the main problem is not the legal requirement or not, but the fact that you never want to be on the other side of an AML check, they are pretty..invasive (and they tend to freeze all your assets if they have some doubt,
then
ask questions -- at least that's what i hear from some of the bank compliance friends).

text: The fact the exchange runs AML checks shields you from that (assuming you pass the check with them)

text: Thanks for the information Alessio. My current situation is that I would be contracted to develop strategies that trade on citibet (An illegal exchange) using a citibet wallet that would not be in my name, but would be in the name of my employer. Do you think it makes a difference that the account would not be in my name?

text: Which money are you going to use? Theirs?  And do you have a piece of paper that says you are working for them?

text: <@UQ379K087> Assuming you're being paid a fee or a wage and not getting a share of the winnings; whilst there might be some vey minor illegality on your part in theory no one is ever going to bother you for that. Just make sure you get the money.

elements.text: Assuming you're being paid a fee or a wage and not getting a share of the winnings; whilst there might be some vey minor illegality on your part in theory no one is ever going to bother you for that. Just make sure you get the money.

text: Also, make you sure the money you get is clean (as much as you can ;-)

elements.text: Also, make you sure the money you get is clean (as much as you can ;-)

text: I would be putting no money into it. I would just be being paid a day rate from a sports betting company based in the Isle of Man.

text: In that case you will be on the hook for any illegality.

elements.text: In that case you will be on the hook for any illegality.

text: That said - I'd be astonished if the law ever came after you, you just might get snagged up in AML as suggested above. The risk of that is lower if you're being paid by a legitimate company but it's not zero.

elements.text: That said - I'd be astonished if the law ever came after you, you just might get snagged up in AML as suggested above. The risk of that is lower if you're being paid by a legitimate company but it's not zero.

text: Essentially : You can't legally take part in an unlawful activity even if your part in it isn't illegal in itself - e.g. getaway driver.

elements.text: Essentially : You can't legally take part in an unlawful activity even if your part in it isn't illegal in itself - e.g. getaway driver.

text: I worked for someone in Australia who used Citibet extensively. I canâ€™t speak for the laws in the UK but in Australia it was illegal for an offshore gambling entity to offer gambling services to Australians, but not illegal for Australians to use them.

elements.text: I worked for someone in Australia who used Citibet extensively. I canâ€™t speak for the laws in the UK but in Australia it was illegal for an offshore gambling entity to offer gambling services to Australians, but not illegal for Australians to use them.

text: I developed Citibet software for a client. I was paid as a developer. I see absolutely nothing to worry about if you are supplying code and being paid to supply code. You aren't being paid to run it, so it's not like being a "getaway driver"

elements.text: I developed Citibet software for a client. I was paid as a developer. I see absolutely nothing to worry about if you are supplying code and being paid to supply code. You aren't being paid to run it, so it's not like being a "getaway driver"

text: The suppliers of video editing software aren't liable for its use

elements.text: The suppliers of video editing software aren't liable for its use

text: Also remember that rules change over time. What once might have been legal, now might not be. This is especially true of overseas bookmakers offering to Australian citizens. Many of these agencies were legal a few years ago

elements.text: Also remember that rules change over time. What once might have been legal, now might not be. This is especially true of overseas bookmakers offering to Australian citizens. Many of these agencies were legal a few years ago

text: All my work for clients was under contract and the contract stated in general the services I provided, i.e. developing and delivering software. If clients are using Citibet they tend to do it through an agent, and the actual organisational structures they use to fund these accounts tend to be "hidden" from view, or at least there are a couple of levels of indirection

text: That's not his situation. He's putting in money. Even if he wasn't; if you know that the law is being broken and you participate in it then you're part of the enterprise and in this case there would really be no ambiguity about that. That's why a getaway driver is held responsible for a robbery whilst an unwitting taxi-driver wouldn't be even though they might provide an identical service. Like I said, I don't think he needs to worry because in real life the chances of anyone coming after him are negligible, but he wants to know where he stands and it's quite clear that he would be part of the enterprise and answerable for his role in any law breaking. Whether there is any illegality is another question, I don't know what the law is on the Isle of Mann.

elements.text: That's not his situation. He's putting in money. Even if he wasn't; if you know that the law is being broken and you participate in it then you're part of the enterprise and in this case there would really be no ambiguity about that. Like I said, I don't think he needs to worry because in real life the chances of anyone coming after him are negligible, but he wants to know where he stands and it's quite clear that he would be part of the enterprise and answerable for his role in any law breaking. Whether there is any illegality is another question, I don't know what the law is on the Isle of Mann.

text: Have spoken directly. If you actually fund it with your own money, then that is indeed a different case. If the investor sets up the structures and contracts out development, that's my case. And there are many examples in between. The best option is to seek proper legal advice with respect to the structures setup. That's what I would do in that situation

text: It can get very complicated. For instance, I was contracted by a company in Guernsey, while I resided in Australia. Something may be legal in one jurisdiction but not others. I could supply software that is illegal to use in Australia for a company that was legally entitled to use it. And once you start betting with Asian bookmakers it can get very murky. That's why I do the simple stuff for myself :wink:

elements.text: It can get very complicated. For instance, I was contracted by a company in Guernsey, while I resided in Australia. Something may be legal in one jurisdiction but not others. text: My question is still this: what law is being broken by the person using an unlicensed exchange? I understand that an unlicensed exchange or bookmaker is breaking the law by offering betting services to UK customers. But I cannot find anything that says it is illegal for a UK citizen to use them. I am not saying this is the case but I am looking for some concrete evidence either way.
